questions.text: A 22-Year-old G2P1 with 39weeks of gestation presents with a history of fever, pain abdomen, generalized weakness, nausea. She has no comorbidities. History of contact with hepatitis B infection in the family is present. She was admitted and samples were sent for lab investigations. HBsAg was found positive. She developed labor and delivered a 3kg normal child by normal vaginal delivery. True statements are - 1. Breastfeeding is contraindicated 2. Neonate is given HBIG 0.5ml im within 12hrs of birth 3. Neonate is given HBIG O.5ml im within 24hrs of birth 4. Active immunization of HB vaccine given im at a separate site 5. Active immunization of HB vaccine contraindicated Select the correct answer from the given below code:
questions.explanation:
Solution:

2 and 4 The given clinical case scenario is that of Hepatitis B infection in pregnancy. Management of HBV during pregnancy: HBV infection can be prevented by vaccination, and the recombinant vaccine is safe in pregnancy. A seronegative pregnant woman should have HB immunoglobulin (HBIG), 0.06 mL/kg IM, soon after exposure and a second dose after one month. Then she should be given recombinant DNA vaccine intramuscularly 1 mL, three doses at 0, 1, and 6 months. All infants born to HBsAg-positive mothers should have HBIG 0.5 mL IM within 12 hours of birth. (STATEMENT 2) Active immunization with HB vaccine (0.5 mL) is also given IM at a separate site at the same schedule . This is very effective (85–95 percent) in protecting the infant from HBV infection. Breastfeeding is not contraindicated.(STATEMENT 1)

Highyeild:

Hepatitis B virus (HBV): The virus is transmitted by parenteral route, sexual contact, vertical transmission and also through breast milk. The risk of transmission to fetus ranges from 10% in first trimester to as high as 90% in third trimester and it is specially high (90%) from those mothers who are seropositive to hepatitis B surface antigen (HBsAg) and 'e'-antigen (HBeAg). Neonatal transmission mainly occurs at or around the time of birth through mixing of maternal blood and genital secretions. Approximately 25% of the carrier neonate will die from between late childhood to early adulthood. hosis or hepatic carcinoma, HBV is not teratogenic Maternal infection : The acute infection is manifested by flu like illness as malaise, anorexia, nausea and vomiting. In majority, it remains asymptomatic. Jaundice is rare and fever is uncommon. Clinical course (HBV) : Nearly 90-95% of patients clear the infection and have full recovery. 1% develop fulminant hepatitis resulting massive hepatic necrosis. 10-15% become chronic and 10% of these chronic cases suffer from chronic active hepatitis, cirrhosis and hepatocellular carcinoma. Diagnosis is confirmed by serological detection of HBsAg, HBeAg (denote high infectivity) and antibody to hepatitis B core antigen (HBcAg) and HBV DNA titer (107-10¹¹). Screening: All pregnant women should be screened for HBV infection at first antenatal visit and it should be repeated during the third trimester for 'high risk' groups (intravenous drug abusers, sexual promiscuity, hemophilics, patients on hemodialysis or having multiple sex partners).

Extraedge:

Similar to HIV, perinatal transmission of HBV depends on maternal viral load. Lamivudine and HBIG effectively reduce the transplacental transmission of HBV to the fetus. Lamivudine is given at 150 mg/day for 34 weeks.

questions.text: A 25-Year-old Primigravida with 28 weeks of gestation presents with abdominal pain, the passage of high-colored urine, nausea, and nocturnal pruritus. She has no comorbidities. No history of fever or loose stools. Her previous lab investigations and use are normal. On examination, P-90/min, BP-122/84mmHg, afebrile, saturation normal, RR-12/min, pallor +, Jaundice +. Abdominal examination shows fundus just above umbilicus, vertical lie, FHR-140/min. Lab investigations show normal Hb - 10g/dL, WBC, and platelets. Serum bilirubin 2.5mg percent. Increased levels of AST, ALT, and Serum Alkaline phosphatase. The diagnosis is:
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Obstructive cholestasis The given clinical case scenario is that of Icterus gravidarum or obstetric cholestasis. Obstetric cholestasis (OC) is the second most common cause of pregnancy jaundice, the first being viral hepatitis. The overall incidence is 1.2–1.5 percent of pregnant Indian women. Bile stasis in the bile canaliculi with the rise in conjugated bilirubin is probably due to excess circulating estrogen. A similar manifestation is also observed in women taking contraceptive pills. Genetic, familial and abnormal progesterone metabolism have been observed. The manifestations usually appear in the last trimester. The onset is insidious; generalized pruritus is the predominant symptom; weakness, nausea, or vomiting may occur. Jaundice is slight. There is a rise in AST, ALT, and serum alkaline phosphatase levels. Bilirubin level rarely exceeds 5 mg percent. A liver biopsy shows no evidence of necrosis but offers the features of intrahepatic cholestasis.

Highyeild:

Cholestatic jaundice of pregnancy/cholestatic hepatosis/icetrus gravidarum/recurrent jaundice of pregnancy: Idiopathic cholestasis of pregnancy is the 2nd most common cause of jaundice in pregnancy (first one being viral hepatitis). It is characterized by accumulation of bile acids in the liver with causing pruritus and jaundice due to estrogen excess. Clinical features: Manifestations appear in the last trimester (beyond 30 weeks) and only occasionally in the late 2nd trimester. The cardinal clinical finding/1st symptom to appear is severe generalized pruritis with a predilection for the palms and soles. Pruritis precedes laboratory findings by a mean of 3 weeks and sometimes by months. Jaundice is slightⓇ (Bilirubin levels rarely exceed 5 mg) and seen in 10% patients. Cholestasis it tends to recur in subsequent pregnancies (recurrence rate = 50%), or with estrogen containing contraceptives.. OCP's are contraindicated in females with h/o cholestasis during pregnancy

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options: - Option: B. Viral hepatitis would have symptoms of fever, nausea, diarrhea, flu-like illness, malaise, anorexia, etc. Viral markers would also be positive. Option: C. In Hyperemesis gravidarum, increased vomiting leading to dehydration, electrolyte imbalance etc., is seen. Option: D. HELLP is considered if there is any history of PIH, hemolysis, and thrombocytopenia

Extraedge:

Investigation: Rise in S. bile acids is the earliest/the most consistent change/Best marker for cholestasis. There is a 10-100 fold increase in s. cholic acid followed by s. chenodoxycholic acid. Serum bilirubin levels are increased (rarely more than 5 mg%) Q and increase is always in direct bilirubin. Serum alkaline phosphatase is raised. Q SGOT/SGPT levels are normal to moderately elevated (seldomexceed 250 U/L) Q . Liver biopsy, which is rarely done shows no necrosis, no cholestasis. Dyslipedemia is present. Prognosis: There is no increased incidence of maternal mortality Symptoms disappear within two weeks postpartum. Jaundice usually disappears within Weeks following delivery. Pruritis as a rule persists longer than jaundice. Increase chances of PPH and cesarean section. There is increased incidence of prematurity, low birth weight babies, sudden IUD and Meconium aspiration in fetus

questions.text: A 26-Year-old primigravida with 35 weeks of gestation presents with a history of pain abdomen, dark-colored urine, nausea, and vomiting. She has no comorbidities. On examination, her P- 90/min, BP-128/84mmHg, RR-12/min, afebrile, saturation normal, pallor +, and Jaundice +. Abdominal examination shows fundus in-between umbilicus and xiphisternum, vertical lie, cephalic presentation, FHR-140/min, and tenderness in the right hypochondrium. Lab investigations showed Hb-7g/dL, AST - and ALT increased highly up to ten times, S.Bilirubin -15mg/dL, prolonged coagulation profile, and RBS- 70mg/dL. The management includes all except -

options.label: B
options.text: Counselling about the condition of subsequent pregnancy

options.label: C
options.text: Vaginal or Cesarean section, whichever is earlier

questions.explanation:
Solution:

None of the above The given clinical scenario is that of acute fatty liver in pregnancy. This condition is associated with a very high incidence of mortality. All the options are correct and will be done in such cases.

Highyeild:

Acute fatty liver of pregnancy/Acute yellow atrophy of the liver: It is a rare condition occurring in third trimester (mean gestational age of weeks) It is the the M/C cause of acute liver failure during pregnancy. Aetiology It is associated with disorders of fatty acid transport and oxidation-deficiency of LCHAD enzyme, i.e. long chair hydroxyl aceyl coenz A dehydrogenase Risk is increased in case of First pregnancy, male fetuses, preeclampsia, maternal obesity and multiple pregnancy.

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options: - Option. A. Correction of coagulation is necessary as the coagulation profile is severely deranged and would lead to increased morbidity and mortality. Option. B. Counselling about the condition is necessary for further pregnancies as the chance of recurrence in subsequent pregnancies is high. Option. C. Immediate termination of pregnancy is required in such cases as prolongation of pregnancy would worsen the condition. It occurs due to a long-chain beta hydroxyacyl Co A dehydrogenase enzyme deficiency, causing the fatty acid accumulation.

Extraedge:

Clinical features: Patients present in the third trimester (generally at 37 weeks) with nonspecific symptoms like nausea, vomiting, anorexia, vague abdominal discomfort and malaise. rea In many women, persistent vomiting is the main symptom. AFP should also be suspected in any woman who presents with new onset nausea and malaise in third trimester. boo This is followed by jaundice (progressive in nature) after about one week. In 50% cases-features of preeclampsia viz-hypertension, proteinuria and oedema are present. In almost all severe cases, there is profound endothelial cell activation with capillary leakage causing hemoconcentration, hepatorenal syndrome, ascites, and sometimes pulmonary edema. Fetal death is more common in cases with severe hemoconcentration. Stillbirth possibly follows diminished uteroplacental perfusion, but is also related to more severe disease and acidosis. There is maternal leukocytosis and thrombocytopenia. The syndrome typically continues to worsen after diagnosis. Hypoglycemia is common, and obvious hepatic encephalopathy, severe coagulopathy, and some degree of renal failure develop in approximately half of women.

questions.text: A 28-Year-old G2P1 with 26 weeks of gestation presents with a history of pain abdomen radiating to the back up to the shoulder, pain usually occurs after intake of food and lasts for 3-4 hours. There is also a history of loose stools. She has no comorbidities. On examination, P-90/min, BP-124/86mmHg, afebrile, saturation normal, RR-16/min, pallor +, Jaundice +. Abdominal examination shows fundus just above umbilicus, vertical lie, FHR-140/min. Her previous lab investigations and use are normal. S. Bilirubin increased, LFT deranged. Usg abdomen was done and showed gallstones and obstruction of the ileum due to impaction of the stone. The management in this condition is:
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Laparoscopic cholecystectomy The given clinical scenario points towards cholelithiasis in pregnancy. SYMPTOMATIC CHOLELITHIASIS: Incidence is about 1 in 2,000 pregnancies. It is the second most common nongynecological condition that needs surgery during pregnancy. Initial management is conservative. Elective endo cystectomy is done in the second trimester or puerperium. Deterioration of clinical situation despite medical therapy or recurrent biliary colic needs cholecystectomy regardless of trimester. Laparoscopic cholecystectomy can be done in the second trimester of pregnancy safely.

questions.text: A woman, 25 -Year-old G1P0, presents at nine weeks of gestation with complaints of vomiting with increased frequency, epigastric pain, and decreased urination. On examination, pt was dehydrated, hypotensive tachycardiac, slightly yellowish skin discoloration, and had acetone breath. Lab investigations show Na-120meq/l, K-2meq/l, liver enzymes elevated, urine -dark colored, increased specific gravity, and acetone is present. What is the diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Hyperemesis gravidarum Since the patient is primi and presents in the first trimester with vomiting and features of shock with acetic breath points towards hyperemesis gravidarum. Although few these days due to potent antiemetics and antihistaminics. It is limited to the first trimester and more in the first pregnancy and younger age group. It is due to increased HCG, which rises at six weeks, peaks at 9-10 weeks, and subside by 16 weeks. However, other hormones, like estrogen progesterone, thyroxine, prolactin, leptin, and adrenocortical hormones, are also implicated. A, D -both are the same, aka obstetric cholestasis, which presents more often in 3rd trimester and presents with generalized pruritis. Vomiting is not severe and has increased bile salts. It is not related to shock-like features. C-AFLP is the most common cause of acute liver failure in pregnancy. Presents in 3rd trimester and has features of acute liver failure like hypoglycemia, encephalopathy, and coagulopathy.

Highyeild:

DEFINITION: It is a severe type of vomiting of pregnancy which has got deleterious effect on the health of mother and/or incapacitates her in day-to-day activities. The adverse effects of severe vomiting are-dehydration, metabolic acidosis (from starvation) or alkalosis (from loss of hydrochloric acid), electrolyte imbalance (hypokalemia) and weight loss.

questions.explanation:
Solution:

Hepatitis E

Highyeild:

Remember Fulminant is more common in hepatitis E. less common in hepatitis C and rare in hepatitis Maternal mortality is very high (15-20%). Perinatal transmission is uncommon. Chronic carrier state is present. Hepatitis E (HEV) : Hepatitis E is the most important cause of non-A, non-B hepatitis in developing countries like Maternal mortality is very high in fulminant type. Medical termination of pregnancy does not alter the prognosis of the patient.

Extraedge:

All pregnant females should be screened for HBV infection in their first antenatal visit and repeated in the last trimester. Screening of HBV is done by determination of HBsAg . Maximum transmission of HBB infection occurs at the time of delivery. Hence MTP is not recommended. in the case of the first trimester. There is no evidence that cesarean section lowers the risk of vertical transmission. Breastfeeding is not contraindicated in case of hepatitis.
